awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Greener Processes for the Sustainable Development of Bio-Based Polyesters
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of green separation and processing strategies to produce bio-based polymers is beneficial to ensure environmentally sustainable materials for future generations. Current monomer production methods typically use petroleum and require hazardous processes. Biomass offers diverse alternate starting materials for polymer chemistries. However, current strategies for isolating monomers from biomass and their polymerizations are limited and often not sustainable in practice. The development of sustainable bio-based polymers requires a holistic approach that tackles key sustainability issues associated with monomer sourcing and extraction, polymer creation, and end-point feedback. This project seeks to utilize residual biomass sources, green extraction techniques, and appropriate polymer syntheses to incorporate structurally rigid monomers (i.e. pentacyclic triterpenols) into the backbones of polymer networks and elucidate the fundamental relationship between processing, structure, and properties of these polyesters derived from natural feedstocks. Key considerations include the methodologies by which feedstocks are sourced, separated, and subsequently translated into useful polymers. Ultimately, knowledge gained will provide impetus for and education in the transformation of bio-refined products into macromolecules that meet the diverse needs of society.

Specific objectives target a fundamental understanding of the processing-structure-property relationships of bio-based polymers derived from green separation techniques. The project will holistically consider the choice of feedstock, extraction technique, polymer synthesis, and polymer degradation to ultimately produce environmentally sustainable processes and products. An iterative approach will use sustainability metrics throughout and will evaluate these metrics to determine the overall process viability from economic and environmental perspectives. By integrating process sustainability metrics into traditional processing-structure-property relationship methodology used in polymer development, the approach will shift the conventional polymer design paradigm to comprehensively address both polymer function and sustainability via the following interconnected, concurrent aims: (I) Leverage green solvent extraction to produce enriched monomer fractions from renewable feedstocks, (II) Sustainably develop polyester thermoplastics and thermosets derived from fractionated biomass, and (III) Evaluate process technoeconomic and life cycle sustainability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This project integrated green separations of biomass feedstocks with various polymer synthesis techniques to produce bio-based plastics.  The approach utilized a holistic process that considers sustainability at each stage. We focused on betulin as a building block for biobased polyesters because (1) it can be extracted from birch bark in high yields and (2) its structure enables facile incorporation into polymer backbones with high potential for favorable thermal and mechanical properties in the resulting polymers. 

Betulin and other triterpenoids were separated from birch bark using green solvent extraction and new, yet easily applied separation techniques.  Green and/or biobased solvent candidates were screened for high yields of betulin as well as selectivity against other known compounds in bark.  The extracts were analyzed via methods developed and refined to determine the chemical compositions of the samples.  Process development included evaluation of techniques for bulk extraction from birch bark as well as an additional extract separation using water as an antisolvent.  Overall, the developed process utilized green and biobased solvents to produce solid extracts with relatively high betulin yields and selectivities especially given the limited number of processing steps required.  The extraction procedure was scaled up to enable quantities viable for polymer synthesis. 

Polyester thermosets were prepared and characterized using betulin from pure sources as well as bark extracts to evaluate purity-structure-property relationship in polyesters derived from bark. A one-pot solventless polymerization at moderate temperatures using biobased co-monomers was used to fabricate these thermosets. Depending on the extraction method used, polyester thermosets polymerized from extracts show similar glass transition temperatures and thermal stabilities to their counterparts fabricated with pure betulin. Additionally, itaconic acid was evaluated as a co-monomer as it is a non-toxic biobased monomer that can undergo both UV and thermal curing. Two different preparation strategies were developed in partnership with our collaborators at Rowan University. Incorporation of itaconic acid imparted favorable properties, including enhanced glass transition temperatures and thermal stability, regardless of preparation method. These results were published in ACS Sustainable Chemistry and Engineering. Towards evaluating end-of-life characteristics, a method to accelerate and quantify the degradation of polyester thermosets was applied and optimized, and kinetic models were used to quantify degradation rates to inform how these plastics may degrade in the environment after use.  

Εconomic and life cycle metrics of the overall process indicate that the process is promising (low E-factor, high renewability, potential for competitive selling price) but that further process improvements and iterations can help to improve process energy.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

The grant has enabled individualized mentorship of twelve undergraduate students at Lafayette College on research techniques, experimental data analyses, and scientific communication. Over half of the students come from backgrounds under-represented in engineering. The undergraduate researchers trained and supported under this award have attained high-quality, publishable results and are co-authors on published and pending manuscripts. Students contributed not only to the research objectives, but also manuscript writing and peer review.  The project has supported six student presentations at national meetings. Three students were recognized with awards to recognize the quality of their research. These experiences have inspired three undergraduates to continue their education by pursuing PhDs in the fields of sustainability and/or polymers. 

Through the duration of the project, environmental sustainability concepts were woven into materials science and engineering coursework at Lafayette College at both the introductory and upper-level, impacting approximately 75 students/year. Additionally, students in their senior design course are introduced to the concepts of life cycle analysis and the principles of green engineering. Furthermore, a student project team (4 students) worked specifically on the technoeconomic and life cycle aspects associated with this project, where they were successfully mentored to gain a better understanding of both the course material and sustainability within process design.  

This project increased research infrastructure at Lafayette College through the purchase of a GPC/HPLC system equipped with both a refractive index and UV-Visible detector, expanding capabilities at the College to quantify polymer molecular weight distributions and extract compositions. 

The grant strengthened an interdisciplinary research collaboration between three faculty members at two PUIs. Together, we have hosted a symposium on the Sustainable Production of Biobased Polymers for three consecutive years at the 2021, 2022, and 2023 ACS Green Chemistry and Engineering Conference. Our students have benefited from rich conversations, site visits, and collaborative opportunities. It also strengthened the PIs ability to build and maintain a sustainable research program with undergraduates, and supported their professional development at meetings, including three invited presentations at national conferences.

The research outcomes may provide societal benefits in the development of sustainable techniques for green solvent extraction and production of bio-based alternatives to current polymers from non-renewable feedstocks. The students educated and mentored through this project may contribute to providing these societal benefits throughout their careers.
